Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of A Dual-Beam Focus Ion-Beam (FIB) System for Nanotechnology Biomedical and Energy Research

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is acquisition of a dual beam focus ion beam (FIB) system, which will permit synergistic opportunities for nanotechnology, biomedical and energy research at Wayne State University (WSU). The approach is to use the FIB system as a central tool for several current and future projects, which urgently demand the ability to fabricate novel three-dimensional nanostructures and nanodevices in situ. This is a capability uniquely offered by FIB.

Intellect Merit: The sub-100 nm resolution three-dimensional patterning capabilities of FIB through milling/deposition will facilitate many research projects that require custom fabricated complex nanostructures and nanosystems. Consequently, FIB will significantly improve the quality and creativity of research at WSU in a broad range of areas from the development of devices and instrumentation (AFM, NSOM, scanning probe) to biomedical applications (biophysics, DNA sequencing, nanofluidics, single cell analysis, imaging, biosensor) to energy research (characterization of battery materials, catalyst and nanomaterials).

Broader Impact: The success of this proposal will significantly enhance WSU capabilities for nanofabrication and material characterization. FIB will be available to the entire WSU campus, other universities and local industry. Together, we estimate that this proposed FIB will impact more than 100 users from 20 research groups. For local industry, it will serve as a resource for advanced manufacturing, product prototyping and material characterization. This proposal represents a unique opportunity for training under-represented groups, which comprise 41% of WSU?s enrollment. The PIs will integrate FIB in their on-going projects and FIB in training of students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: The goal of this MRI project was the acquisition of a state-of-the-art a dual-beam focused ion beam (FIB) system for research and education in various fields ranging from nano-device engineering to biotechnology to renewable energy science and technology at Wayne State University (WSU). Wayne State University has established a strong nanotechnology program to promote collaborative and creative research from many departments including physics, chemistry, biomedical engineering, electrical and computer engineering, materials science, and school of medicine. However, a significant limitation of the program in the past was the lack of a modern instrument for nanolithography and nanomachining.  The acquisition of FIB permitted synergistic opportunities for material research, nanotechnology, biomedical and energy research at WSU.  After acquisition, the quality of research and the training of undergraduates and graduate students have been improved. The instrument also enhanced WSU’s ability to attract and retain new faculty in the strategic areas of nanotechnology, biotechnology, and energy.

 

Intellectual Merit: FIB significantly improved the quality and creativity of research at WSU in a broad range of areas from the development of devices and instrumentation (AFM, NSOM, scanning probe) to biomedical applications (biophysics, DNA sequencing, nanofluidics, single cell analysis, imaging, biosensor) to energy research (characterization of battery materials, catalyst and nanomaterials). The FIB greatly enhanced our research and training programs, and improved the competitiveness of our work as we seeked external funding and expanded the scope of on-going federal projects.

 

Broader Impact: The acquisition of FIB enhanced our capabilities for nanofabrication and material characterization. The FIB has became a shared resource and managed by the Nanofabrication Core (nFab), a shared university facility which managed high-end instruments for nanofabrication and material characterization at WSU. FIB is open to the entire WSU campus, other universities, local industry, as well as the University of Windsor in Canada. To date, the FIB has benefited more than 50 graduate students and postdoc fellows for their research and training. The PI has developed projects and taught undergraduate students advanced nanomanufacturing using FIB. The exposure made them well trained technical professionals and helped immensely in their future careers. In addition, the FIB has served as a resource for advanced manufacturing and material characterization tool, and several industrial users had used the equipment, including Nissan, GM and BASF.
